fields.description: As a cloud administrator, I would like to be able to register all user facing services at once so I don't have to register them all individually.
fields.summary: SRVSEP - Administrative script for registration of all user facing services

comments.body:
Straw man proposal:

{code}
euca-register-user-services -H HOSTHERE -p OPTIONALPORTHERE NAMESUFFIXHERE
{code}

would register:

* AS_XX - AutoScaling service
* COM_XX - Compute service (was Eucalyptus)
* CW_XX - CloudWatch service
* EUA_XX - Euare service
* LB_XX - Elastic Load Balancing service
* OS_XX - Object Storage service
* TOK_XX - Tokens service

where XX is the suffix supplied by the user.  A partition argument is not necessary for user facing services.

An example usage would be:

{code}
euca-register-user-services -H 10.111.1.66 66
{code}

Which would result in services registered with names such as "AS_66".
What became of the "named service collection" concept that [~decker] explained to me a while ago?  Seems to me that {{euca-register-service $collection_name}} would make sense for this.
Not sure how that would work, how would we know where the services are or what to call them? (service names should be unique). Have we identified service collections other than user facing services?

The idea is to have a pseudo-component with a service builder that somehow identifies the services that comprise it (e.g. via hardcoding or annotations) and then registers them appropriately to actually get everything set up.  The individual service names could potentially be identical; we're more or less treating the collection as a unit anyway, similar to the way we do for traditional CLC-based services.  For some reason the CloudControllerColocatingBootstrapper comes to mind as something similar in spirit to this.

The big reasons for doing it that way as opposed to client-side with a special tool are twofold:
# DescribeServices could potentially be made to report the overall status of the services that comprise instances of this pseudo-component.
# It allows us to enforce all-or-nothing semantics for this collection of services, whereas doing it client-side allows for asymmetry.

I'd just call them "public services" or maybe even "front end services" as far as command and component naming goes.  When I asked around people understood what those meant more readily than "user-facing services".

As far as I know there is no current requirement (PRD) that would cover enforcing all-or-nothing semantics for user facing service registration. Groupings of services for display could also be handled on the client which would more easily allow display in the users preferred format.

Both front end and user facing services seems like reasonable terminology to me, public seems a bit too vague/generic. Perhaps [~jloza] prefers one of these or has other naming suggestions for this service grouping (EC2, AutoScaling, CloudWatch, ELB, IAM, etc) which distinguishes these services from internal / administrative services.

I think both "front-end" and "user-facing" are a bit confusing when talking about these services. I know these are the gateway to the rest of the cloud, but generally when people talk about the "front end" they are talking about the software used to access these services, like the console and euca2ools. I would not use either of those (front end nor user facing), IMHO.
[~jloza], it would be best to use the proper names for the end points (EC2, Autoscaling, S3, etc). Or simply, client tools (euca2ools/user console) and server (eucalyptus).

I like [~kedwards] idea of using "server" somehow for this collection. 

That being said, really the best thing would be to get actual customer input for this. Maybe [~lwade] or [~mharnish] or [~bcarpenter] or [~shashi] might have insight or be able to run this by customers fairly quickly to get their idea of nomenclature for this group of services that would work well for the command/collection name. That would be my recommendation.
Given that this should be completed today, I'll go with my original suggestion and people can open bugs if they feel strongly about it.
Sounds good, if we get commentary from the folks I mentioned above (I hope we do) we can open a bug.

A euca-register-user-services command is added for registration of user facing services.

{code}
euca-register-user-services -H HOST NAME_SUFFIX
{code}

Where HOST is the host where the services are located and NAME_SUFFIX is the partial name for the registered services, e.g.:

{code}
# euca-register-user-services -H 10.111.1.67 67
Created new partition 'autoscaling'
SERVICE	autoscaling    	autoscaling    	AS_67          	LOADED    	26  	http://10.111.1.67:8773/services/AutoScaling	arn:euca:bootstrap:autoscaling:autoscaling:AS_67/
Created new partition 'cloudwatch'
SERVICE	cloudwatch     	cloudwatch     	CW_67          	LOADED    	26  	http://10.111.1.67:8773/services/CloudWatch	arn:euca:bootstrap:cloudwatch:cloudwatch:CW_67/
Created new partition 'compute'
SERVICE	compute        	compute        	COM_67         	ENABLED   	26  	http://10.111.1.67:8773/services/compute	arn:euca:bootstrap:compute:compute:COM_67/
....
{code}

Fix Verified

Installed Packages
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 4.0.0
Release     : 0.0.917.20140423gitac6b0379.el6

All UFS can be registered with this command
